stream_context.summary: Stream focused on integrating Biobak’s new, performance-optimised Mario model and on early design work for a Portal-style “light bridge” triggered by an arcade button; Kaze also outlined several planned low-level cache optimisations for the N64 engine.

development_findings.summary: Biobak’s revised Mario model is 30-44 triangles lighter (639→595) and cuts TMEM usage by ~40 %, while adding improved eyes, shoe shine, cap logo, vertex colours and eyebrows.
development_findings.quote: This model has 170 triangles less than 64 Mario… and it has smaller textures than the original Mario model.

development_findings.summary: Vertex colours were largely removed so most parts now render in one cycle; buttons were converted to I4 and re-combined to look shiny instead of glowing.

New dynamic palette system for Mario’s cap: Kaze wrote an HSV hue-shift routine so all 16 colours in the CI8 cap logo palette can be recoloured for power-ups instead of changing a single primitive colour.
development_findings.quote: Instead of setting one colour we now need to HSV shift the entire palette to the new colour… that’s what I wrote.

development_findings.summary: Combiner experimentation showed N64 anti-aliasing breaks when attempting a two-cycle lerp; solution was to switch the head texture from I4 to CI8 and add 32 B so AA works again.
Too many concurrent dynamic lights (≈>5) tint Mario green; Kaze suspects cumulative light limits in RSP/RDP.
Portal-style light bridge concept: fully transparent at first, becomes solid and colour-coded after button press, then fades; gradient may use Layer 4 or dithering for clarity.
development_findings.quote: There needs to be a warning that the bridge is gonna disappear, so that’s why we can’t go straight to alpha.

development_findings.summary: Planned cache hacks: (1) read i-cache + thread history in idle thread to pre-fetch next thread, (2) RCP task send will only hit/invalidate recent addresses, (3) OS functions will run in exclusive dirty cache lines to avoid RAM.
development_findings.quote: I’m gonna read the instruction cache… so I can predict the thread that runs next and prefetch instructions into iCache.

development_findings.summary: Fast64 export bug caused collision/lighting errors; workaround was to delete duplicate objects and re-export.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed major excitement and pride over the new model but also visible frustration while fighting N64 combiner limits.
context_findings.quote: I have to get this to work… this is the first time here I am feeling somewhat hopeful.

context_findings.summary: He joked about sponsorships: turned down a dildo company offer, is pursuing a Manscaped deal and already wrote ad-copy lines with Biobak.
context_findings.quote: We are probably getting a Manscaped sponsorship. I can talk about my shaved balls on YouTube videos next.

context_findings.summary: Mentioned personal schedule: ending stream early for an appointment at Zeina’s parents, hinting at balancing dev work and family life.
Kaze has begun using FL Studio for YouTube videos and teased a humorous rap project with Salwar rooted in Big Boo’s Haunt music.

biobak.summary: Delivered the updated Mario model, documented every texture change (eyes, shoes, sideburns, folds) and guided Kaze through correct combiner/shading settings.
biobak.quote: 39 % TMEM usage decrease… makes the old Mario model look like a beta model.

biobak.summary: Pushed for removal of unnecessary vertex colours and provided feedback on butt-crease, lighting and button material.

zeina.summary: Suggested greyscale export idea for the button shine; participated briefly in colour-discussion and arranged a post-stream family visit with Kaze.

key_stories.title: The New Mario Model
key_stories.summary: Biobak hands Kaze a drastically optimised Mario. Kaze must integrate it without losing anti-aliasing or cap-colour functionality. Combiner limits, palette issues and lighting bugs derail progress, but after hours of shader surgery the model renders flawlessly – complete with a subtle butt-crease.
key_stories.challenge: Import a higher-fidelity Mario while using less N64 resources.
key_stories.process: Iterative Fast64 imports, combiner rewrites, palette HSV-shift coding, switching head texture from I4 to CI8, real-hardware testing.
key_stories.outcome: Model now looks “insanely good”, saves 40 % TMEM, and preserves performance; Kaze plans a Patreon screenshot.
key_stories.key_quote: This looks so insanely good – this model is lower poly and lower resolution than the original, yet better in every way.

key_stories.title: Concepting the Light Bridge
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a Portal-style light bridge that appears after pressing an arcade button and later fades. He debates gradient clarity, warns of disappearance cues and explores dithering and Layer 4 solutions.
key_stories.challenge: Create an unambiguous, performant visual effect that signals solid vs. disappearing states on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Texture experiments, alpha-fade plans, discussion of dithering, arcade button modelling.
key_stories.outcome: Concept defined; implementation deferred to future stream.
key_stories.key_quote: There needs to be a warning that the bridge is gonna disappear, so we can’t go straight to alpha.

open_questions.context: Kaze outlined three speculative techniques (thread prediction, selective hit/invalidate, exclusive dirty cache) but none are implemented yet.
questions: Have any of these cache hacks been prototyped on hardware?
What performance gains does Kaze expect or has he measured?
Could these techniques introduce instability or incompatibility with real consoles?

open_questions.context: Only a rough concept exists; questions remain about warning cues, colour schemes, and level design impact.
questions: What gameplay scenarios will use the light bridge?
How will the player be taught its timing and fade behaviour?
Are there technical limits on its length or number of active bridges?

open_questions.context: Mario turned green when too many lights were active; Kaze suspects a five-light ceiling.
questions: What is the exact light limit on real hardware?
How will level artists be constrained to avoid colour shifts?
Can the engine cull or prioritise lights automatically?

open_questions.context: Kaze joked about Manscaped and turned down a dildo sponsorship.
